meaning: 한번 고려해 보다. (생각해 볼 가치가 있어)
example:
A: Yo, you ever thought about starting a podcast?
B: I've entertained the idea a few times, for real.
A: No cap, you got the voice for it.
B: Preciate it. I just don't know if I got the time.
A: We could just start small and see how it goes.
B: Facts, I'm down to entertain that, say less.
chinese: 调成无声 (Tiáo chéng wúshēng) / 手机静音 (Shǒujī jìngyīn)

example:
A: Is the new iPhone really worth it?
B: Honestly, you get a lot of bang for your buck with that camera.
A: Facts, the cinematic mode is crazy.
B: For real, it's almost a pro tool now.
A: I guess I'm hitting the Apple store today.
B: Say less, I'm coming with you.
chinese: 马上到 (Mǎshàng dào) / 这一会儿就走 (Zhè yīhuìr jiù zǒu)

example:
A: Did you hear the intro to the new Kendrick track?
B: Man, this build up is crazy! I'm hyped.
A: No cap, I feel like the drop is gonna be legendary.
B: The anticipation is killing me, for real.
A: Here it comes... wait for it...
B: Oh my god, that beat is straight fire!
chinese: 我等不及了 (Wǒ děngbùjí le) / 迫不及待 (Pòbùjídài)

example:
A: You've been staring at that wall for five minutes.
B: Oh, sorry. I'm just deep in thought.
A: Penny for your thought? Is everything okay?
B: Honestly, I'm just stressed about the move, deadass.
A: Don't trip, we got this handled together.
B: Facts, I appreciate you looking out.
chinese: 干得漂亮 (Gàn de piàoliang) / 好样的 (Hǎoyàngde)

example:
A: Yo, why are you so mad about a 5-minute delay?
B: I'm just tired of the MTA always trippin', man.
A: Don't get worked up, it is what it is.
B: I know, but it happens every single day, for real.
A: Take a breath, we'll get there eventually.
B: Facts, I'm just tryna maintain my peace.
chinese: 小菜一碟 (Xiǎocài yī dié) / 易如反掌 (Yìrúfǎnzhǎng)

example:
A: We gotta leave in like 2 minutes!
B: What's the hurry? We're not even late yet.
A: I'm not tryna be the last one there, deadass.
B: Chill, they haven't even started the intro yet.
A: Fine, but if we miss the first act, it's on you.
B: Say less, I'll pay for the next round if that happens.
chinese: 不客气 (Bù kèqi) / 别客气 (Bié kèqi)

meaning: 도대체 왜 이렇게 늦어지는 거야? (무슨 일 있어?)
example:
A: The line hasn't moved for 10 minutes. What's the holdup?
B: Dunno, maybe the system went down or something.
A: This is crazy, I'm tryna get my coffee and bounce.
B: Deadass, everybody in here looks annoyed AF.
A: Let's just go to the spot across the street.
B: Say less, I'm right behind you.
chinese: 没问题 (Méi wèntí) / 没事儿 (Méishìr)

example:
A: I wasn't sure if the fit would work, but you pulled it off!
B: Preciate it, I was lowkey nervous about the color combo.
A: Nah, it's straight fire. You look like a whole influencer.
B: Deadass? Thanks, man.
A: For real, you got that confidence, no cap.
B: You already know, I'm tryna stay fly.
chinese: 保重 (Bǎozhòng) / 注意安全 (Zhùyì ānquán)

example:
A: My phone screen cracked, but it still works.
B: Man, could be worse. At least the touch is fine.
A: Facts, but it looks so ugly now, deadass.
B: Just put a screen protector over it and chill.
A: I guess, but I'm still annoyed.
B: It is what it is, don't let it ruin your vibe.
chinese: 玩得开心 (Wán de kāixīn) / 好好玩 (Hǎohǎo wán)

example:
A: Yo, I got some crazy tea about what happened at the party.
B: No cap? Hit me with it!
A: So, basically, Mike and Sarah got into a huge argument.
B: Deadass? I thought they were vibing.
A: Apparently not, it was straight drama.
B: Spill everything, I'm all ears.
chinese: 回头见 (Huítóu jiàn) / 待会儿见 (Dài huìr jiàn)

meaning: 나는 약속은 꼭 지켜. (확고한 결심을 했어 - 맥락상 특정 목표에 대한 헌신)
example:
A: You still going through with the travel plan?
B: Facts, I am committed to Poland. No turning back now.
A: No cap? That's a huge move.
B: I've been planning this since day one, deadass.
A: I'm hyped for you, man. Take lots of pics.
B: You already know, my IG is gonna be fire.
chinese: 好久不见 (Hǎojiǔ bùjiàn) / 老长时间没见了 (Lǎo cháng shíjiān méi jiàn le)

example:
A: The rain ruined our picnic plans.
B: Facts, but the silver lining is we can finally check out that indoor gallery.
A: Oh true, I've been wanting to go there, deadass.
B: See? It worked out in the end.
A: You always find the vibe, no cap.
B: Tryna keep it positive, always.
chinese: 怎么了? (Zěnme le?) / 最近怎么样? (Zuìjìn zěnmeyàng?)

meaning: 나 지금 기세가 좋아! (연달아 성공하고 있어)
example:
A: Yo, you just finished another project?
B: Facts, I'm on a roll this week.
A: No cap, you're really crushing the game lately.
B: Just tryna keep the momentum going, you know?
A: Keep that same energy, for real.
B: Locked in and ready for the next one.
chinese: 你好吗? (Nǐ hǎo ma?) / 怎么样? (Zěnmeyàng?)

example:
A: Did you see the new draft of the project?
B: Yeah, I've already incorporated your suggestions into the layout.
A: No cap? It looks way better now, preciate it.
B: Facts, your input really helped vibe the whole thing up.
A: Let's show the client and see what they think.
B: Say less, I'm hitting send right now.
chinese: 我挺好的 (Wǒ tǐng hǎo de) / 还可以 (Hái kěyǐ)

example:
A: What is he doing over there?
B: Just jerking off instead of actually working, deadass.
A: Facts, he’s been on his phone for an hour.
B: For real, if the boss sees him, he's cooked.
A: Should we say something?
B: Nah, let him figure it out on his own.
chinese: 谢谢 (Xièxie) / 多谢了 (Duō xiè le)

meaning: 그는 너를 기만할 거야. 너를 가지고 놀 거야. (속이다 혹은 헛된 기대를 주다)
example:
A: He said he'd help me with the promotion.
B: Don't trust him, he will just jerk you off and never do it.
A: Deadass? He seemed so sincere though.
B: Facts, he’s a straight-up silver-tongued snake.
A: I guess I'll just handle it myself then.
B: Smart move, don't let him play you.
chinese: 打扰了 (Dǎrǎo le) / 请问 (Qǐngwèn)

example:
A: Yo, you still in the city?
B: Yeah, I'm around. You tryna link up?
A: Facts, I'm near Union Square right now.
B: Oh word? I'm like 5 blocks away.
A: Say less, come meet me at the park.
B: Bet, I'll be there in ten.
chinese: 对不起 (Duìbuqǐ) / 抱歉 (Bàoqiàn)

example:
A: What do you think about the new office layout?
B: IMO, it's way too cramped in here now.
A: Facts, I can barely move without hitting someone.
B: Lowkey tryna ask the boss to let me work from home.
A: Say less, I'm with you on that one.
B: Deadass, let's start a petition.
chinese: 没关系 (Méiguānxi) / 算了 (Suànle)

example:
A: Yo, it's getting brick outside. Make sure you bundle up!
B: Facts, I'm already grabbing my heavy puffer.
A: Good move. Keep warm and stay healthy, no cap.
B: You too, man. Stay cozy inside.
A: Catch you later, stay safe.
B: Word, you too.
chinese: 没事 (Méishì) / 没关系 (Méiguānxi)

example:
A: How was the walk by the river?
B: Man, the breeze was refreshingly cool. I needed that.
A: Facts, it's been way too humid in the city lately.
B: For real, it felt so much better out there.
A: I'm tryna head there later for some fresh air.
B: Do it, it's a whole vibe, deadass.
chinese: 那就行 (Nà jiù xíng) / 还可以 (Hái kěyǐ)

example:
A: I started working on the marketing plan.
B: Wait, isn't that my responsibility?
A: Sorry, I didn't mean to step on your toes.
B: I'd prefer if you didn't overstep your bounds.
A: I was just trying to get a head start.
B: I appreciate it, but let's not tread on my territory.
chinese: 我不知道 (Wǒ bù zhīdào) / 谁晓得 (Shéi xiǎodé)

meaning: 서서 마시는 술. (사교적인 자리에서 가볍게 한잔)
example:
A: Yo, we meeting for a full dinner?
B: Nah, let's just grab a vertical drink and catch up.
A: Word, that works for me. I gotta be home early anyway.
B: Facts, there's a cool spot with no seating anyway.
A: Say less, I'll meet you there at 7.
B: Bet, see you then.
chinese: 我同意 (Wǒ tóngyì) / 我也是这么想的 (Wǒ yěshì zhème xiǎng de)

meaning: 많은 걸 시사하네. (말하지 않아도 딱 알겠어)
example:
A: He didn't even show up to the meeting.
B: Man, it speaks volumes about how much he cares.
A: Facts, he’s been lowkey checked out for weeks.
B: For real, I think he's already looking for a new spot.
A: I wouldn't doubt it, deadass.
B: It is what it is, we gotta keep moving.
chinese: 我很忙 (Wǒ hěn máng) / 我事儿多着呢 (Wǒ shìr duō zhe ne)

meaning: 설명이 필요 없네. (그 자체로 증명이 돼)
example:
A: You think this portfolio is good enough?
B: Honestly? Your work speaks for itself, no cap.
A: Preciate it, I'm just nervous about the client's reaction.
B: Don't even trip, they're gonna love it.
A: I hope so, I put in a lot of hours, deadass.
B: Facts, and it shows. Level up.
chinese: 我饿了 (Wǒ è le) / 肚子咕咕叫了 (Dùzi gūgū jiào le)

meaning: 거저 얻은 거나 다름없어. (진짜 싸게 잘 샀어)
example:
A: Yo, check out this watch I got at the thrift store.
B: No way, that looks expensive! How much?
A: Only 20 bucks, deadass. It was a steal.
B: For real? That's insane. It looks like it's worth way more.
A: Facts, the guy didn't know what he had.
B: You really lucked out on that one, no cap.
chinese: 我渴了 (Wǒ kě le) / 想喝点水了 (Xiǎng hē diǎn shuǐ le)

primary: We should stock up it's a steal
example:
A: Yo, they're selling these cases of water for 2 bucks!
B: Deadass? We should stock up, it's a steal.
A: Facts, we're definitely gonna need it for the party.
B: Grab like five cases before they sell out.
A: On it, help me carry these to the car.
B: Say less, I got you.
chinese: 我累了 (Wǒ lèi le) / 没劲儿了 (Méi jìnr le)

meaning: 여기 뭐가 맛있어요? (추천할 만한 거 있나요?)
example:
A: Yo, first time at this spot. What's good here?
B: Man, you gotta try the spicy rigatoni. It's fire.
A: No cap? I've been craving some good pasta.
B: For real, everyone talks about it for a reason.
A: Say less, I'm ordering that right now.
B: You won't regret it, deadass.
chinese: 我很无聊 (Wǒ hěn wúliáo) / 闲得发慌 (Xián de fāhuāng)

example:
A: Yo, can you plot these charts for the meeting?
B: Facts, I'll have them ready in like 10 minutes.
A: Preciate it, the client really needs to see the growth trends.
B: For real, I'll make them look extra fly, no cap.
A: Say less, I know you got that design touch.
B: You already know, I'm on it.
chinese: 我很高兴 (Wǒ hěn gāoxìng) / 开心极了 (Kāixīn jí le)

example:
A: Yo, why is the app trippin'?
B: You forgot to install the packages, deadass.
A: My bad, I just pulled the latest code.
B: For real, just run 'npm install' and you're good.
A: Facts, I completely blanked on that.
B: It happens, just get it done so we can test.
chinese: 我很伤心 (Wǒ hěn shāngxīn) / 难过死了 (Nánguò sǐ le)

example:
A: These designs are fire, how do I save images from the folder?
B: Just right-click and export them as PNGs, deadass.
A: Word, I need to send these to the marketing team.
B: Facts, they're gonna love the new aesthetic.
A: For real, it's a whole different vibe now.
B: Say less, just make sure you save them in high res.
chinese: 我病了 (Wǒ bìng le) / 身体不舒服 (Shēntǐ bù shūfu)

example:
A: Yo, how do I access images from the shared drive?
B: Just enter the password and you're in, deadass.
A: No cap? I thought it was more complicated than that.
B: Nah, it's straight to the point. Catch the vibes.
A: Preciate the info, man.
B: You already know.
chinese: 我很冷 (Wǒ hěn lěng) / 冻死了 (Dòng sǐ le)

similar: 2. I never gave it a thought
example:
A: Did you think about moving to the suburbs?
B: Honestly, it never even crossed my mind.
A: Really? It's so much quieter out there.
B: I guess it never occurred to me as an option.
A: You're such a city person through and through.
B: Exactly, suburbs weren't even on my radar.
chinese: 我很热 (Wǒ hěn rè) / 挺热的 (Tǐng rè de)

example:
A: Yo, why is the submit button disabled?
B: You gotta fill out all the fields first, deadass.
A: Oh true, I missed the email line.
B: Facts, the system won't let you through without it.
A: Got it, it's enabled now.
B: Say less, hit send.
chinese: 我很害怕 (Wǒ hěn hàipà) / 吓死我了 (Xià sǐ wǒ le)

example:
A: Can I just reboot the server and hope for the best?
B: Nah, that will not work. You gotta fix the config file.
A: Deadass? I was tryna take the easy way out.
B: For real, shortcuts just lead to more bugs.
A: Fine, I'll do it the right way.
B: Smart move, no cap.
chinese: 我很惊讶 (Wǒ hěn jīngyà) / 真没想到 (Zhēn méi xiǎngdào)

example:
A: Should I try to fix the wiring myself?
B: Deadass, do not attempt that. You'll blow the whole circuit.
A: Is it really that dangerous?
B: Facts, calling a pro is the only move here.
A: Alright, I'll chill. Don't want any smoke.
B: Good choice, stay safe.
chinese: 我很生气 (Wǒ hěn shēngqì) / 气死我了 (Qì sǐ wǒ le)

example:
A: What's the desired output format for the report?
B: They want it in PDF, no cap.
A: Word, I'll make sure the charts are clean too.
B: Facts, the presentation is everything with this client.
A: Say less, I'll have it ready by five.
B: You already know.
chinese: 我很兴奋 (Wǒ hěn xīngfèn) / 激动极了 (Jīdòng jí le)

example:
A: Should we fix the UI or the backend first?
B: Backend security must take precedence, deadass.
A: Facts, we can't have people's data getting leaked.
B: For real, the flashy stuff can wait until the foundation is solid.
A: Word, let's lock in on the security updates.
B: Bet, I'm already on it.
chinese: 我很自豪 (Wǒ hěn zìháo) / 挺得意的 (Tǐng déyì de)

example:
A: Yo, did he just ignore the guidelines we set?
B: Deadass, he's doing his own thing and it looks messy AF.
A: For real, we gave him a whole doc for a reason.
B: We gotta talk to him before this gets out of hand.
A: Facts, we can't have the whole project looking trippin'.
B: Say less, I'm calling a meeting.
chinese: 我很紧张 (Wǒ hěn jǐnzhāng) / 心里怦怦跳 (Xīnlǐ pēngpēng tiào)

example:
A: This documentation is so easy to read!
B: Facts, I used clear and logical headings to organize the flow.
A: No cap, it makes finding things a breeze.
B: That's the goal. Nobody wants to hunt for info.
A: Level up on the doc game, man.
B: Preciate that, just tryna stay professional.
chinese: 我不明白了 (Wǒ bù míngbai le) / 糊里糊涂的 (Húlihútú de)

example:
A: Yo, why did you break this up so much?
B: You gotta keep paragraphs short to maintain the reader's attention, deadass.
A: Facts, long blocks of text are lowkey intimidating.
B: For real, people just wanna scan and get the main idea.
A: Smart move, it feels way more inviting now.
B: You already know.
chinese: 我迷路了 (Wǒ mílù le) / 找不到北了 (Zhǎo bù dào běi le)

example:
A: Man, this email is just one big dense text block.
B: Deadass, I'm not even gonna read that. Too much work.
A: Lowkey unprofessional, no cap.
B: For real, tell them to send bullet points or something.
A: Facts, I'll just ask for a summary.
B: Best move, don't waste your time.
chinese: 我准备好了 (Wǒ zhǔnbèi hǎo le) / 完事了 (Wán shì le)

example:
A: Can you summarize the meeting for me?
B: Yeah, I'll send you some bullet points right now.
A: Preciate it, I just need the key takeaways, deadass.
B: Word, it's straight to the point, no fluff.
A: You're a real one for that.
B: You already know.
chinese: 我做完了 (Wǒ zuò wán le) / 搞定了 (Gǎo dìng le)

example:
A: He explained the project like I was a child.
B: He can be so condescending sometimes.
A: I hate it when he's being patronizing.
B: He's always acting superior to everyone else.
A: It's really hard to work with someone like that.
B: Tell me about it, he's always looking down his nose.
chinese: 我迟到了 (Wǒ chídào le) / 来晚了 (Lái wǎn le)

example:
A: How do I set up the new environment?
B: Check the README, I made some numbered lists for the steps.
A: Oh word, this makes it so much easier to follow.
B: Facts, just go through them one by one and you're good.
A: Nailed it, thanks man.
B: Any time, stay safe.
chinese: 我来早了 (Wǒ lái zǎo le) / 提前到了 (Tíqián dào le)

example:
A: What were the key takeaways from the seminar?
B: Basically, we need to focus on mobile-first design, deadass.
A: Facts, that's where all the traffic is going anyway.
B: For real, if we don't adapt, we're cooked.
A: Glad we're on the same page.
B: You already know, stay locked in.
chinese: 我到了 (Wǒ dào le) / 就在这儿呢 (Jiù zài zhèr ne)

example:
A: How did you organize the brainstorm notes?
B: I grouped ideas by department to make it cleaner, no cap.
A: Smart, now everyone can just focus on their own part.
B: Facts, it's way more efficient than just a random list.
A: Level up on organization, man.
B: Trying my best, for real.
chinese: 我在那儿 (Wǒ zài nàr) / 到地方了 (Dào dìfang le)

example:
A: Should I rank these ideas by importance?
B: Nah, just use unordered lists for now, deadass.
A: Word, I'll just keep it simple and clean.
B: Facts, we can organize them properly later.
A: Say less, I'm on it.
B: No cap.
chinese: 我到家了 (Wǒ dào jiā le) / 回来了 (Huílái le)

example:
A: How do I follow the setup guide?
B: Look for the ordered lists, they show the priority, deadass.
A: Facts, I don't wanna skip anything important.
B: For real, just go from 1 to 10 and you're good.
A: Nailed it, thanks for the heads up.
B: You already know.
chinese: 我出去了 (Wǒ chūqù le) / 不在呢 (Bù zài ne)

example:
A: Yo, does the intro lead into the climax well?
B: Facts, the whole story flows logically, no cap.
A: Preciate it, I was worried about that middle section.
B: Nah, you nailed the pacing, deadass.
A: Word, glad it's coming together.
B: It's a whole movie, for real.
chinese: 我回来了 (Wǒ huílái le) / 又见面了 (Yòu jiànmiàn le)

primary: scan and understand key points quickly
example:
A: Why did you use so many headers?
B: So the client can scan and understand key points quickly, deadass.
A: Smart move, they probably don't have time for a deep dive.
B: Facts, everyone in this city is always in a hurry.
A: No cap, but this makes it way easier for them.
B: That's the goal, no cap.
chinese: 我要走了 (Wǒ yào zǒu le) / 撤了 (Chè le)

example:
A: I think the font is too small.
B: Facts, it's lowkey trippin' with the readability.
A: Should I bump it up to 12pt?
B: For real, make it 14 so nobody has to squint.
A: Word, now it's way more accessible.
B: Facts, looks premium now.
chinese: 我这就来 (Wǒ zhè jiù lái) / 马上就到 (Mǎshàng jiù dào)

example:
A: Should I delete these links at the bottom?
B: Nah, you gotta preserve any and all citations, deadass.
A: Why? They look kinda messy.
B: Facts, but we need them for credibility, no cap.
A: Got it, I'll keep them in.
B: Good move, stay professional.
chinese: 我留下来 (Wǒ liú xiàlái) / 不走了 (Bù zǒu le)

example:
A: How should I credit the original author?
B: Just embed citations throughout the text, deadass.
A: Like 'according to source X' style?
B: Facts, it makes the whole thing look more legit.
A: On it, I'll make sure they're visible.
B: Say less, you got this.
chinese: 我在等呢 (Wǒ zài děng ne) / 候着呢 (Hòu zhe ne)

example:
A: Stop explaining it like I’m five. 
B: I was just trying to be helpful. 
A: You’re being incredibly patronizing. 
B: My bad, I didn't mean to talk down to you. 
A: Just give me the facts, okay? 
B: Got it, I'll keep it professional from now on.
chinese: 我在找呢 (Wǒ zài zhǎo ne) / 寻思着呢 (Xún si zhe ne)

example:
A: Where should I put the main topic sentence?
B: Always at the beginning of paragraphs, no cap.
A: Word, that way people know what to expect immediately.
B: Facts, don't bury the lead, deadass.
A: Got it, restructuring now.
B: You already know.
chinese: 我听着呢 (Wǒ tīngzhe ne) / 愿闻其详 (Yuàn wén qí xiáng)

example:
A: Do I need to tell everyone where I got this info?
B: For sure, always mention the sources, deadass.
A: I don't want anyone thinking I'm faking facts.
B: Facts, credibility is everything in this game.
A: Word, adding the list now.
B: Level up.
chinese: 看着呢 (Wǒ kànzhe ne) / 盯着呢 (Dīngzhe ne)

example:
A: Where should I put the ID numbers?
B: Just put them in front of headers to stay organized, no cap.
A: Word, that makes the navigation way smoother.
B: Facts, it helps people jump to specific parts quickly.
A: Say less, I'm updating the whole doc.
B: Bet, looking good.
chinese: 我在想呢 (Wǒ zài xiǎng ne) / 盘算着呢 (Pánsuan zhe ne)

example:
A: Yo, what's up?
B: Not much, just chilling. You?
A: Same, just tryna survive this humidity.
B: Facts, it's straight brick in the shade though.
A: Lowkey cold? That's crazy.
B: For real, the weather trippin'.
japanese: 元気（げんき）？／調子（ちょうし）どう？
chinese: 我在学呢 (Wǒ zài xué ne) / 琢磨着呢 (Zuómó zhe ne)

example:

japanese: 久（ひさ）しぶり。／長（なが）い間（あいだ）会（あ）ってなかったね。
chinese: 我在干活呢 (Wǒ zài gànhuó ne) / 忙着呢 (Mángzhe ne)

example:

chinese: 我在玩儿呢 (Wǒ zài wánr ne) / 耍呢 (Shuǎ ne)

example:

japanese: ゆっくりでいいよ。／焦（あせ）らなくていいよ。
chinese: 我在歇着呢 (Wǒ zài xiēzhe ne) / 休息呢 (Xiūxi ne)

example:

japanese: 分（わ）かった。／了解（りょうかい）。
chinese: 我在睡觉呢 (Wǒ zài shuìjiào ne) / 梦周公呢 (Mèng zhōugōng ne)

example:

chinese: 我在吃饭呢 (Wǒ zài chīfàn ne) / 嚼着呢 (Jiáo zhe ne)

example:

chinese: 我在喝水呢 (Wǒ zài hēshuǐ ne) / 品着呢 (Pǐn zhe ne)

chinese: 我在做饭呢 (Wǒ zài zuòfàn ne) / 下厨呢 (Xiàchú ne)

chinese: 我在打扫呢 (Wǒ zài dǎsǎo ne) / 收拾呢 (Shōushi ne)

example:

japanese: ちょっと待（ま）って。
chinese: 我在洗呢 (Wǒ zài xǐ ne) / 搓着呢 (Cuō zhe ne)

example:

chinese: 我在看书呢 (Wǒ zài kànshū ne) / 读着呢 (Dú zhe ne)

example:

japanese: もう行（い）かなきゃ。
chinese: 我在写东西呢 (Wǒ zài xiě dōngxi ne) / 记着呢 (Jì zhe ne)

example:

japanese: 今（いま）向（む）かってる。
chinese: 我在说话呢 (Wǒ zài shuōhuà ne) / 聊着呢 (Liáo zhe ne)

example:

chinese: 我在唱歌呢 (Wǒ zài chànggē ne) / 吼两嗓子 (Hǒu liǎng sǎngzi)

example:

japanese: 私（わたし）の知（し）る限（かぎ）りでは。
chinese: 我在跳舞呢 (Wǒ zài tiàowǔ ne) / 蹦着呢 (Bèng zhe ne)

example:

japanese: というか…／つまり…
chinese: 我在跑步呢 (Wǒ zài pǎobù ne) / 颠儿着呢 (Diānr zhe ne)

meaning: 그런 것 같아. (약간의 확신이 부족할 때)
example:

chinese: 我在溜达呢 (Wǒ zài liūda ne) / 走着呢 (Zǒu zhe ne)

example:

japanese: それでいいよ。／構（かま）わないよ。
chinese: 我在开车呢 (Wǒ zài kāichē ne) / 握着轮子呢 (Wòzhe lúnzi ne)

meaning: 스님처럼 내면을 돌아보며 깨달음을 얻는 정신적 전환 상태

japanese: 悟（さと）りを開（ひら）く（僧侶（そうりょ）のような精神（せいしん））
chinese: 我在飞呢 (Wǒ zài fēi ne) / 上天了 (Shàngtiān le)

example:

chinese: 我在游泳呢 (Wǒ zài yóuyǒng ne) / 划水呢 (Huáshuǐ ne)

example:

chinese: 我在跳呢 (Wǒ zài tiào ne) / 蹦跶呢 (Bèngda ne)

example:

chinese: 我在站着呢 (Wǒ zài zhànzhe ne) / 立着呢 (Lì zhe ne)

example:

chinese: 请稍等 (Qǐng shāo děng) / 稍微等一下 (Shāowēi děng yīxià)

example:

chinese: 帮我个忙 (Bāng wǒ gè máng) / 搭把手 (Dā bǎ shǒu)

japanese: 気（き）にしないで。／なんでもない。
chinese: 不用了，谢谢 (Bùyòng le, xièxie) / 不客气，不用 (Bù kèqi, bùyòng)

japanese: 君（きみ）次第（しだい）だよ。／任（まか）せるよ。
chinese: 你决定 (Nǐ juédìng) / 听你的 (Tīng nǐ de)

example:

japanese: パスするよ。／やめとくよ。
chinese: 我不去了 (Wǒ bù qù le) / 我还是算了吧 (Wǒ háishì suànle ba)

example:

chinese: 没什么大不了的 (Méi shénme dàbùliǎo de) / 小事一桩 (Xiǎoshì yī zhuāng)

chinese: 迟到总比不到好 (Chídào zǒng bǐ bù dào hǎo) / 亡羊补牢 (Wángyángbǔláo)

chinese: 保持联系 (Bǎochí liánxì) / 常联系 (Cháng liánxì)

meaning: 잘 가, 편히 쉬어. (작별 인사나 진정하라는 말)

chinese: 别太累了 (Bié tài lèi le) / 慢慢来 (Mànman lái)

chinese: 好久没见了 (Hǎojiǔ méi jiàn le) / 有阵子没见了 (Yǒu zhènzi méi jiàn le)

chinese: 祈祷好运 (Qǐdǎo hǎoyùn) / 菩萨保佑 (Púsà bǎoyòu)

japanese: よかったね！／やるじゃん！
chinese: 真为你高兴 (Zhēn wèi nǐ gāoxìng) / 真棒 (Zhēn bàng)

japanese: いいなぁ。／ついてるね。
chinese: 你真走运 (Nǐ zhēn zǒuyùn) / 幸运儿 (Xìngyùn'ér)

chinese: 很高兴知道这个 (Hěn gāoxìng zhīdào zhège) / 知道了 (Zhīdào le)

example:

japanese: とにかくありがとう。
chinese: 还是得谢谢你 (Háishì děi xièxie nǐ) / 心领了 (Xīnlǐng le)

example:

japanese: どういうこと？／どういう意味（いみ）？
chinese: 你什么意思? (Nǐ shénme yìsi?) / 怎么讲? (Zěnme jiǎng?)

meaning: 무슨 소리 하는 거야? (황당하거나 이해 안 갈 때)
example:
A: I heard we're moving the office to New Jersey.
B: What are you talking about? No way, deadass.

B: For real? That intern is always trippin', no cap.
A: I hope so, Jersey is too far.
B: Word.
japanese: 何（なに）言（い）ってるの？
chinese: 你在说什么呀? (Nǐ zài shuō shénme ya?) / 瞎说什么呢 (Xiā shuō shénme ne)

example:
A: The line for this coffee is insane. 
B: Seriously, what’s the hold up? 
A: I think their espresso machine is broken. 
B: What's taking so long to fix it? 
A: Maybe we should just go to the other spot. 
B: Good call, let's move it along.
japanese: 何（なに）がつかえてるの？／なんで遅（おく）れてるの？
chinese: 在等什么呢? (Zài děng shénme ne?) / 怎么还没动静? (Zěnme hái méi dòngjing?)

meaning: 오해는 하지 마. (내 말 본뜻은 그게 아냐)
example:
A: You don't like the new design?
B: Don't get me wrong, deadass, it's nice, but it's just not the right vibe for this client.
A: No cap? I thought they'd love the neon colors.
B: For real, they're more into that minimalist aesthetic.
A: Facts, I'll tone it down then.
B: Best move, no cap.
japanese: 誤解（ごかい）しないでね。／悪（わる）く取（と）らないで。
chinese: 别误会 (Bié wùhuì) / 别想歪了 (Bié xiǎng wāi le)

example:

B: No hard feelings, deadass. I know you were swamped with work.
A: Preciate that, man. I lowkey felt bad about it.
B: For real, don't even trip. We'll link up next week.
A: Say less, I'm down.
B: Bet.
japanese: 悪（わる）く思（おも）わないでね（恨（うら）みっこなしで）。
chinese: 别往心里去 (Bié wǎng xīnlǐ qù) / 没记仇 (Méi jìchóu)
